bibl.title: Letter from Robert F. Woodward to Philip Showalter Hench, October 26, 1954

div1.p: Woodward informs Hench that the Cubans successfully passed a resolution giving Finlay the sole credit for discovering the transmitting agent of yellow fever. He also states it is unfortunate that no credit was given to those who were able to prove Finlay's theory. He encloses a letter from Harold M. Randall.

div1.head: Letter from Robert F. Woodward to Philip Showalter Hench, October 26, 1954
div1.opener:
ADDRESS OFFICIAL COMMUNICATIONS TO
THE SECRETARY OF STATE
WASHINGTON 25, D. C.
DEPARTMENT OF STATE
WASHINGTON
October 26, 1954
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
It was very helpful of you to send me your letter
of October 5 concerning the assistance that you might
be able to give to the Cuban delegation at a meeting
scheduled to take place in Rome, where the Cubans wish
to support their assertion that Dr. Carlos Finlay was
the first serious proponent that yellow fever is caused
by the Aedes Aegypti mosquito.

Having sent your letter promptly to the American
Embassy at Habana, I have just received a reply of
October 19, of which I enclose a copy for your information.
The information concerning the date of the proposed con-
ference was incorrect; the conference has already taken
place; and the Cubans were able to effect the unanimous
approval of a resolution which appears to give Dr. Finlay
virtually sole credit for the discovering of the transmit-
ting agent of yellow fever and the application of this
knowledge to health in the tropics. While the Cuban dele-
gation was undoubtedly satisfied with this resolution, it
is of course unfortunate that no credit was given to those
who were able to prove the correctness of Dr. Finlay's
theory.
div1.closer:
With appreciation and best wishes,
Sincerely yours, Robert Woodward Robert F. Woodward
Deputy Assistant Secretary
for Inter-American Affairs
Enclosure
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
